snippet: The Caucasus region and the former Soviet republics in Central Asia have become a vital recruiting ground for the Islamic State and a growing source of worry for the Kremlin.
abstract: Russian authorities are concerned about foothold Islamic State has gained in Caucasus region, where it has been reported at least 2,000 residents have left to join group in Syria; as many as 7,000 Islamic State recruits have come from Russia and former Soviet Union; part of Russian government's fears stem from resurgence of violence decade ago, when Chechen terrorists conducted series of attacks in country.

byline.contributor: Ivan Nechepurenko contributed reporting from Berekei, and Rukmini Callimachi from Hasaka, Syria.

lead_paragraph: The Caucasus region and the former Soviet republics in Central Asia have become a vital recruiting ground for the Islamic State and a growing source of worry for the Kremlin.

headline.main: For Russia, Links Between Caucasus and ISIS Provoke Anxiety
headline.print_headline: Islamic State’s Recruiting in Caucasus Prompts Growing Concern in Russia

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
